pullRequest.body:
This PR adds two main results about positive semidefinite matrices:
- a positive semidefinite matrix has a unique positive semidefinite square root;
- if `A` is positive semidefinite then `x* A x = 0` implies `A x = 0` (proof extracted from #8594).

Co-authored-by: Adrian WÃ¼thrich (@awueth)

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

-->

Thanks Eric and Johan for your comments!
OK, here's a version which should hopefully address all the comments so far.

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7253505651/job/19760239242)
In the interest of merging this sooner, I will turn some of my other comments that I'm *not* including below into a separate PR.

Two last minor things.

bors d+

Perhaps slightly nicer:
```suggestion
  rw [StarOrderedRing.nonneg_iff] at hx
  induction hx using AddSubmonoid.closure_induction' with
  | Hs y hy =>
    obtain âŸ¨z, rflâŸ© := Set.mem_range.mpr hy
    rw [star_mul, star_star]
  | H1 => exact star_zero _
  | Hmul z _ w _ hz hw => rw [star_add, hz, hw]
```

whitespace:
```suggestion
lemma star_eq_self_of_nonneg {x : R} (hx : 0 â‰¤ x) : star x = x := by
```
I've split these lemma moves to #8810 to shrink the diff.
Can you add a type annotation here?

Also
```suggestion
@[pp_dot]
noncomputable def sqrt := hA.1.eigenvectorMatrix *
```

This is going to be annoying to work with in the goal view, since it will show as `_.sqrt ^ 2 = A`. Either we should make `A` an explicit argument of `sqrt`  so that it prints as `A.sqrt _`, or we should write a custom elaborator that makes it print as `(_ : PosSemiDef A).sqrt`.
In the first case you would also need to rename to `Matrix.sqrt`, right?

I don't think it would be a good idea to rename this to `Matrix.sqrt` -- there might be other notions of square root appropriate for other kinds of matrices (not pos-semidef). Can someone give me a hint how to write custom elaborators?

Here's how to do the second one:
```lean
open Lean PrettyPrinter.Delaborator SubExpr in
@[delab app.Matrix.PosSemidef.sqrt]
def delabSqrt : Delab :=
  whenPPOption getPPNotation <|
  whenNotPPOption getPPAnalysisSkip <|
  withOptionAtCurrPos `pp.analysis.skip true do
    let e â† getExpr
    guard <| e.isAppOfArity ``Matrix.PosSemidef.sqrt 6
    let optionsPerPos â† withNaryArg 5 do
      return (â† read).optionsPerPos.setBool (â† getPos) `pp.proofs.withType true
    withTheReader Context ({Â· with optionsPerPos}) delab

open Matrix

variable {A : Matrix n n ð•œ}  (hA : PosSemidef A)

#check (id hA).sqrt -- (_ : PosSemidef A).sqrt : Matrix n n ð•œ
```
You might have to adjust the 5 and 6 to match the actual number of arguments / position of last argument for `sqrt`
Is this true for non-square `B`?
Please add a test for this using `#guard_msgs in #check`, either in a `test` file or immediately below.
why is it required that `e` is an equiv here? (I understand this lemma is not yours, but if this is easy to fix by replacing it with a general map, it might be worth doing it).
I assume it's probably required that `e` is injective?

The lemma is true as stated for any e (it needn't be injective or surjective -- you need injectivity for the positive-definite version, but not for positive semidef). Mathematically this is just the special case of `conjTranspose_mul_mul_same` when `B` is a matrix of 0's and 1's (with `B i j = 1` iff `e j = i`). However, the proof would need to be completely rewritten; and doing it properly probably require developing some more API about how `mulVec` and `vecMul` interact with `Submatrix`. 

~~Can I suggest that this be pursued separately from this PR?~~

PS. It turns out that the necessary API already exists (specifically `Matrix.submatrix_mul`), so I wrote a new proof for the general case which is shorter than the existing one for equivs. (This required adding a `DecidableEq` assumption on the index set in another lemma further down but I don't think that's a significant loss.)

```suggestion
   and `xá´´ * M * x` is nonnegative for all `x`. -/
```
Done
Can you please golf the example in `Algebra.Order.Ring.Star` using this?
Done
It would be best to put this immediately below `def sqrt` so that the printing takes effect when navigating the proofs in the file.
Done
This should probably be `simp`, along with `sqrt_mul_self` (matching `Real.sqrt_mul_self`) for good measure
Done

I think it would be good to also show:
```lean
lemma sqrt_sq (hA2 : PosSemidef (A ^ 2)) : hA2.sqrt = A :=
  hA2.posSemidef_sqrt.eq_of_sq_eq_sq hA hA2.sq_sqrt
```

Or even better, we'd build on top of #9036 and show that `A ^ n` is positive-semidefinite for any `n`, and then state this as
```lean
lemma sqrt_sq : (hA.pow 2).sqrt = A :=
  let hA2 := (hA.pow 2)
  hA2.posSemidef_sqrt.eq_of_sq_eq_sq hA hA2.sq_sqrt
```

@eric-wieser , I appreciate your feedback, but this constant ping-pong of tiny addition after tiny addition is getting to be a little frustrating. 

Could I ask that you perhaps make a finite list of the additional functionality you'd consider "sufficient" for getting this PR merged, and that once this list is made, you endeavour to resist the temptation to add to it?

This PR is, after all, an outgrowth of #8594, based on code by my student who encountered Lean for the first time this semester. I encouraged him to make a PR because I wanted to demonstrate to him, and the rest of my class at ETH Zurich, that mathlib was a project that welcomed new contributors. We seem to be in some danger of demonstrating the opposite of that.

All this is a bit annoying because `Matrix.IsHermitian.eigenvectorMatrix` is a bare matrix as opposed to an element of `Matrix.unitaryGroup n ð•œ`. We should refactor that. This is either a note to myself or to anyone else who feels so inclined. After that refactor I believe this could be done in a few lines.
```suggestion
  let C := hA.1.eigenvectorMatrix
  let E := diagonal ((â†‘) âˆ˜ Real.sqrt âˆ˜ hA.1.eigenvalues : n â†’ ð•œ)
  suffices : C * (E * (Cá´´ * C) * E) * Cá´´ = A
```

Please factor out this lemma:
```lean
/-- A diagonal matrix is Hermitian if and only if its diagonal entries are selfadjoint. -/
lemma isHermitian_diagonal_iff [DecidableEq n] {d : n â†’ R} :
    (diagonal d).IsHermitian â†” (âˆ€ i : n, _root_.IsSelfAdjoint (d i)) := by
  simp [isSelfAdjoint_iff, IsHermitian, conjTranspose, diagonal_transpose, diagonal_map]
```
Note: this highlights the annoying fact that `Matrix.IsSelfAdjoint` should be protected.
Done

Maybe this instead:
```suggestion
/-- For `A` positive semidefinite, we have `xâ‹† A x = 0` iff `âˆšA x = 0` iff `A x = 0`. -/
theorem PosSemidef.mulVec_tfae [DecidableEq n]
    {A : Matrix n n ð•œ} (hA : PosSemidef A) (x : n â†’ ð•œ) :
    List.TFAE [star x â¬áµ¥ mulVec A x = 0, mulVec hA.sqrt x = 0, mulVec A x = 0] := by
  tfae_have 1 â†’ 2
  Â· intro h
    rwa [â† hA.sq_sqrt, sq, â† mulVec_mulVec, dotProduct_mulVec, â† hA.posSemidef_sqrt.1.eq,
      vecMul_conjTranspose, star_star, hA.posSemidef_sqrt.1.eq, dotProduct_star_self_eq_zero] at h
  tfae_have 2 â†’ 3
  Â· intro h
    rw [â† hA.sq_sqrt, sq, â† mulVec_mulVec, h, mulVec_zero]
  tfae_have 3 â†’ 1
  Â· intro h
    simp [h]
  tfae_finish
```

I'm not convinced by this: the "middle" condition in the TFAE list seems like an artefact of the proof, not something which deserves to go in the statement. I don't feel that adding it outweighs the usability hit that comes with formulating it as a TFAE. 

I also strongly suspect that the equivalence "`star x â¬áµ¥ mulVec A x = 0 â†” mulVec A x = 0`" holds much more generally. It certainly holds for positive-semidef symmetric matrices over any Archimedean linearly ordered field: any such field embeds in the reals (although I think mathlib doesn't know this yet), and the two conditions are both preserved by scalar extension, so the general case follows from the real case. Of course, the vast majority of such fields aren't closed under square roots so the middle condition doesn't even make sense for them. So, with an eye to future generalisations, I'd rather we didn't build square roots into the statement.

This could be a bigger TFAE:
1. PosSemidef A
2. âˆƒ B, A = Bá´´ * B
3. âˆƒ H, H.IsHermitian, A = H * H
4. âˆƒ P, P.PosSemidef, A = P * P
5. A.IsHermitian âˆ§ âˆ€ x âˆˆ spectrum ð•œ A, 0 â‰¤ x -- or another way to say the eigenvalues are nonnegative.

If you would like to leave this for a future PR that's okay.

Personally I don't think TFAE's have any value unless:
* None of the spellings are canonical (`PosSemidef A` clearly is)
* The TFAE makes the proof shorter
(but I would be in favor of an `Iff` lemma for each of those bullets except the first)

Eric, I fundamentally disagree with this. I think that our current tooling for TFAE is the problem. I think we at least need a way to name the things in the list so that they can be used with `List.TFAE.out`.
Since there is evidently not a consensus here as to whether this edit is beneficial, I am going to leave it for a future PR.

My claim is that TFAE's are no good as an API surface because:
* They are unergonomic to use (as you have to refer to the statements by index). This could indeed be addressed by using names, but I don't see ``foo_tfae.out `foo `bar`` being more ergonomic than `foo_iff_bar`.
* They end up with weird asymmetries. You can't possibly put every `foo_iff_$BAR` in the same tfae, as some will have import constraints forcing them to be placed in other files.

TFAEs definitely have their place in setting up APIs, but I claim they should be an implementation detail.

Incidentally, I had a stab at coding up the equivalence 1 â†” 5 from Jireh's suggestion as a freestanding lemma, and it turns out to be much harder than it deserves to be. There seems to be no API linking `Algebra.Spectrum` of a matrix with its eigenvalues at present, so formulations using `spectrum` would need a whole load of extra work elsewhere.

I tried using a formulation based on "IsHermitian.eigenvalues", but I couldn't find a good formulation, because we don't have a definition of "eigenvalues" for a matrix that isn't known to be Hermitian, and I don't know how to write "X and [something which is only well-defined given X]" as a single expression. The best I can do is
```
lemma posSemidef_iff_eigenvalues_nonneg [DecidableEq n] {A : Matrix n n ð•œ} (hA : IsHermitian A):
    PosSemidef A â†” âˆ€ i : n, 0 â‰¤ hA.eigenvalues I := by ...
```
I'm happy to add that to the PR if it's considered useful.
PS: I guess `PosSemidef A â†” âˆƒ (h : IsHermitian A), âˆ€ i : n, 0 â‰¤ h.eigenvalues I` will do the job, although it seems a bit clumsy.

David, you can just avoid the TFAE for now if you would like. Thanks for being willing to try it though. Although the connection between spectrum and eigenvalues *does* exist, it's [Module.End.hasEigenvalue_iff_mem_spectrum](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Basic.html#Module.End.hasEigenvalue_iff_mem_spectrum)

But @eric-wieser TFAEs have tremendous value from a *readability* perspective. Even if you have other `â†”` statements lying around. This alone is enough to merit writing them, even if the full TFAE only holds under special circumstances (i.e., with sufficiently strong type class assumptions).

Moreover, proving a big TFAE is generally *easier* because if you have `n` statements you often only need `n` distinct `tfae_have`s, whereas to prove `1 â†” 2`, ..., `1 â†” n`, you need to show `2 * (n - 1)` different implications. A TFAE with 3 equivalences is arguably of insufficient value to warrant it, but a TFAE with 5 or more I think is easily worthwhile.

> Although the connection between spectrum and eigenvalues does exist, it's [Module.End.hasEigenvalue_iff_mem_spectrum](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Basic.html#Module.End.hasEigenvalue_iff_mem_spectrum)

Yes, I saw that lemma too, but the problem is the next step: we don't have the implication that, for Hermitian `T`, `Module.End.hasEigenvalue T a` implies that `a` is in `IsHermitian.eigenvalues T` (I'm deliberately omitting conversions between matrix and linear-map types here). We have the implication the other way, [LinearMap.IsSymmetric.hasEigenvalue_eigenvalues](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Spectrum.html#LinearMap.IsSymmetric.hasEigenvalue_eigenvalues), but not the way just stated. It wouldn't be all that hard to add, but it's not there as of now.
I started a [Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/TFAE.20discussion/near/408668294) about the use of TFAE in Mathlib.
This lemma now exists as `IsSelfAdjoint.of_nonneg`; can you merge master?
Done

`Î»` is not allowed by the style guide:
```suggestion
  refine âŸ¨fun âŸ¨_, hPâŸ© i â†¦ by simpa using hP (Pi.single i 1), ?_âŸ©
  refine fun hd â†¦ âŸ¨isHermitian_diagonal_iff.2 <| fun i â†¦ star_eq_self_of_nonneg (hd i), fun x â†¦ ?_âŸ©
```
Fixed
At risk of prolonging the review further; should we be skipping `sqrt` and going straight to defining `rpow`? What do you think @j-loreaux?

Probably you already guessed how I would react, but for the record: I am against this in general, sinceÂ it smacks of reinventing continuous functional calculus via the back door (where do we stop? `exp`? `tan`? `riemannZeta`?); and I am even more against trying to do it in this particular PR.

I'm happy for the resolution in this PR to be "add a TODO comment" or "add a comment explaining why generalizing to rpow is a bad idea", rather than actually making the generalization; but I'm not qualified to decide between those options.

(I'd argue that the square root plays a distinguished role because we care a lot about *bilinear forms* on vector spaces -- inner products and their generalisations -- and hence raising to the power 2, and also its inverse, has a distinguished role in the theory. Higher n-linear structures are much less frequently encountered. So that is why I argue that we _should_ have a special implementation of matrix square root, but _not_ of more general matrix powers.)

I agree with David. There's no point reinventing the functional calculus (*especially* not as part of this PR). And indeed, square roots are somehow more important than other roots / functions. (This is a deep claim, but I believe it to be true.) For instance, using only that square roots exist, one can show that a closed two-sided ideal in a Câ‹†-algebra is selfadjoint.

I think it's safe to just call this:
```suggestion
lemma posSemidef_diagonal_iff [DecidableEq n] {d : n â†’ R} :
```

Thanks for adding this. Since we already have the `â†’` direction, maybe you could just add the `â†` direction like so, in order to get dot notation:
```lean
lemma posSemidef_of_eigenvalues_nonneg [DecidableEq n] {A : Matrix n n ð•œ}
    (hA : A.IsHermitian) (h : âˆ€ i : n, 0 â‰¤ hA.eigenvalues i) : PosSemidef A := sorry
```

```suggestion
lemma PosSemidef.of_eigenvalues_nonneg [DecidableEq n] {A : Matrix n n ð•œ}
```
will give `(.of_eigenvalues_nonneg _ _)` dot notation, instead of no dot notation.
oops, I meant to call it `Matrix.IsHermitian.posSemidef_of_eigenvalues_nonneg`. Sorry!
